page.title: 06GRAND UNION CANAL
page.content: {Canals}were built is the 18th century Industrial Revolution to move products and materials to and from markets at a time when roads were in a very poor state. {The Grand Union Canal connected the River Thames in London to Birmingham in the heart of the industrial Midlands. It had many locks, was 200km long and was ready in 1805. The branch from Paddington to Southall was 20km long, had no locks and so made the link faster. The canal was built at a time of cheap labour (mainly Irishmen) using picks, shovels, pulleys, wheel-barrows and horses. Clay was puddled on the pervious bottom. Wooden posts supported the sides. Brickearth soil dug up was used for the building to expand London. {The canal brought {industry and people}to once rural villages like Greenford and Northolt.
